Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: I observed that events related to the same case often share patient attributes such as age, gender, and department assignment.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: By examining the sequence of events and matching patient attributes (e.g., age, gender), I deduced that each 'Register patient' event initiated a distinct case.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I inferred that cases logically proceed according to a care pathway, with activities such as registration, triage, tests, consultations, and discharge following one another.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Events like 'X-ray imaging for patient 45M' were linked to an earlier registration and triage for the same patient, as no other plausible cases matched the patient details.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: I cross-checked the timelines to ensure that no two events with conflicting details (e.g., different patients) were grouped in the same case.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: At one point, I considered grouping patients based on immediate event proximity, but I revised this approach when it conflicted with shared attributes and logical flow.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I identified that events related to one patient were interleaved with events from other cases, so cases needed to be reconstructed out of sequence based on patient attributes.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: I recognized that discharge events (e.g., for 45M) marked the end of corresponding cases, confirming that no further activities belonged to the same patient after these.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Given the recurring discharge follow-ups (e.g., physiotherapy for 28M), I generalized that follow-ups implied the conclusion of a case.
